links.*: Guide to the Names in The Lord of the Rings
The Lord of the Rings: A Reader's Companion

wikitext.*:
'''Sûza''' is the [[Westron]] word for "province, sphere of occupation, division of a realm",{{App|F2}} visible in '''Sûza-t''', "[[The Shire]]".{{PM|II}}, p. 45 ==Etymology== Perhaps the second element ''-za'' related to the [[Adûnaic]] word ''[[zâyan]]'' ("land").Andreas Möhn, "[http://lalaith.vpsurf.de/Tolkien/Fr_Atani.html Etymologies of the Atani languages]", entry ZAY'N ==Inspiration==
'' "[...] actually the ON [[Old Norse]] and mod. Icelandic ''sýsla{{WP|Sýsla}}>'' (Swed. ''syssla'', Dan. ''syssel'', now obsolete in sense ''amt'', but occurring in place-names) was in mind when I said that the real untranslated name of the Shire was ''Súza'' [...] hence it was also said [...] that it was a 'district of well-ordered ''business'''."''{{HM|N}}, p. 775 (entry for ''Shire'')
{{references}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Suza}} [[Category:Westron words]]
